summary: The document is a confidential memo from 21 May 1971, detailing American participation in the World Peace Council (WPC) Conference in Budapest, Hungary, from 13-16 May 1971. It highlights the involvement of various Americans in committee discussions on topics such as European Peace and Security, Indochina Aggression, the Near East, and Discrimination. Notable events include the posthumous awarding of the JOLIOT-CURIE GOLD MEDAL to Reverend Martin Luther KING, accepted by Reverend Ralph ABERNATHY and Reverend Wyatt T. WALKER. The memo also notes the re-election of Herbert APTHEKER and Carlton GOODLETT to the Presidential Board of the WPC and stresses the document's confidential nature.
key_findings: Americans participated in various committees at the WPC Conference, discussing topics like European Peace and Security, Indochina Aggression, the Near East, and Discrimination.
Notable individuals included Stanley FAULKNER, Sylvia KUSHNER, and Ruth GAGE-COLBY, among others.
The WPC awarded the JOLIOT-CURIE GOLD MEDAL posthumously to Reverend Martin Luther KING, accepted by Reverend Ralph ABERNATHY and Reverend Wyatt T. WALKER.
Herbert APTHEKER and Carlton GOODLETT were re-elected to the Presidential Board of the WPC.
The document emphasizes confidentiality and restricted dissemination.
